abstract.p: Mitzi Witkin letter on August 27 Habitats column holds it is ironic not that renters do not know who Allen Ginsberg was but that they are paying $2,000 a month rent (S)

block.p: Regarding the Habitats column about two young men who rent the East Village apartment at 170 East Second Street that Allen Ginsberg once lived in [''Ginsberg Lived Here (You Know, the Poet),'' Aug. 27], the irony is not that they do not know who he was -- the foremost poet of the Beat movement and vocal critic of American materialism. The irony is that they are paying $2,000 a month to rent Ginsberg's former apartment.
One need not speculate on Ginsberg's reaction. To quote from his long poem ''Howl'':

The irony is that they are paying $2,000 a month to rent Ginsberg's former apartment.
One need not speculate on Ginsberg's reaction. To quote from his long poem ''Howl'':
''Moloch whose mind is pure machinery! Moloch whose blood is running money! . . . Moloch whose love is endless oil and stone! Moloch whose soul is electricity and banks!''
